Package ws.rocket.path.annotation

Annotations for describing keys and values of tree nodes so that a tree could be composed at runtime using CDI ( Contexts and Dependency Injection) mechanism.

See: Description

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    KeyBuilder
    Contract for annotated tree node value objects wishing to construct their own tree node key manually.
  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    RootNodeProducer
    Producer for root TreeNodes according to CDI (Contexts And Dependency Injection) standard.
  • Annotation Types Summary 
    Annotation Type Description
    RootNode
    CDI qualifying annotation, which triggers a tree construction where the root node value is with provided name or type.
    TreeNode
    Annotation used on TreeNode values (classes) for describing the node to be constructed where the annotated value object will belong to.

Package ws.rocket.path.annotation Description

Annotations for describing keys and values of tree nodes so that a tree could be composed at runtime using CDI ( Contexts and Dependency Injection) mechanism. This approach for composing a tree is provided as an alternative and is not mandatory. It might not even suit for all needs. For example, this approach requires each tree node to have a value object (as its class must be annotated). However, this annotation based method for constructing the tree could be simple and well enough for most cases.

Tree is constructed when CDI encounters a dependency injection point (field, parameter) with TreeNode type and with RootNode annotation. The annotation refers to the value bean of the root tree node. For example, a Servlet class could request root node: 

 public MyServlet extends GenericServlet {
 
   @Inject
   @RootNode
   private TreeNode root;
 
   private MyDeliveryAlgorithm handler;
 
   public init() {
     this.handler = new MyDeliveryAlgorithm(this.root);
   }
 
   public void service(ServletRequest req, ServletResponse res) {
     this.handler.deliver(req, res);
   }
 }

TreeNode producer uses the data (CDI bean name or type) from RootNode annotation to search for the value bean of the root node. When omitted, the producer uses the field/parameter name for looking up a CDI bean with the same name. An example of a value bean (to complement the previous sample) is following (note the TreeNode annotation!): 

 @Named("root")
 @TreeNode(children = {'client', 'manage', 'browse', 'api' })
 public class Root implements KeyBuilder {
 
   public Object buildKey() {
     return KeysFactory.root();
   }
 }

The previous code sample for a node value illustrates many features but let's look at them individually. First, the class annotation describes the CDI bean names of values belonging to child-nodes (so there will be 4 child-nodes in this example). Their order will be also the same as for their names in this children attribute.

Beans annotated with TreeNode also get a default name as the annotation includes Named annotation. In this example, the bean name is "root". That would be also the TreeNode key value but this class uses the KeyBuilder contract to instantiate its own custom TreeNode key. A key can also be a bean: just add the bean name or type to TreeNode annotation to be looked up when node is created.

Each annotation supports referring to classes either by CDI bean name(s) or Java class(es). Both methods have their pros and cons, however, they cannot be mixed in one annotation declaration. When unsure, referring by class could be preferred as it is less vulnerable to code refactoring (e.g. when renaming a class).
